awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structural Health Monitoring, Diagnosis and Prognosis of Minimally Instrumented Structural Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award will pioneer a novel framework to assess the safety of minimally instrumented structural systems of buildings and bridges.  The ultimate goal of the research is to predict remaining life of instrumented structures with knowledge of the state of damage, of material degradation and incorporating uncertainties in the loading environment. The work will focus on two types of loading that abound in civil engineering and that share many common characteristics with other systems in mechanical/bio-medical and aerospace applications. The project will investigate: (i) seismic load induced low-cycle fatigue damage in building structures and (ii) traffic load induced high-cycle fatigue in bridges. The structural systems of buildings and bridges are large, complex and can only be instrumented with a relatively small number of sensors in relation to the total number of degrees-of-freedom. Monitoring the operational safety of these systems is a significant engineering challenge. The computational methods developed in this project will enable early damage diagnosis and future life prognosis of structural systems using minimal instrumentation. This project will integrate multi-disciplinary research, education, and broadens the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering and mathematics.

The research in this project investigates a new framework for structural health monitoring of structures subjected to cumulative damage such as fatigue. This project deviates from the conventional approach of identifying damage as changes in model parameters. Instead, this project will investigate a novel framework that combines probabilistic damage mechanics and dynamic state estimation. A new algorithm will be developed which will be capable of optimally combining the predictive capabilities of multi-scale finite element models with that of sensor measurements to reconstruct the complete dynamic response of a structure. The reconstructed response allows assessment of the state of cumulative fatigue damage throughout the structure, thus anticipating potential damage before it reaches a critical level. Once the state of damage together with its uncertainty is determined, the condition of the structure can be projected into the future in order to perform probabilistic damage prognosis. The research involves development of computational algorithms, laboratory experiments and field validation using real data from minimally instrumented operational bridge and building structures.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The current state of America’s infrastructure requires advanced technologies capable of monitoring and predicting which infrastructure elements require immediate intervention, and which ones can continue to operate safely (diagnosis), and for how long (prognosis). This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award developed novel framework to assess the safety of minimally instrumented structural systems of buildings and bridges, with special attention to dynamic loading.  The project focused on: (i) seismic load induced low-cycle fatigue damage in building structures and (ii) traffic load induced high-cycle fatigue in bridges. The structural systems of buildings and bridges are large, complex, and can only be instrumented with a relatively small number of sensors in relation to the total number of degrees-of-freedom. Monitoring the operational safety of these systems is a significant engineering challenge. The computational methods developed in this project enable engineers to perform early damage diagnosis and prognosis of structural systems using minimal instrumentation.

The main conclusion from the research carried out as part of this project, are as follows:

a)      It is possible to accurately estimate internal stresses and strains in all members (beams, columns, etc.) of the underlying structure of typical buildings during earthquakes using at least three accelerometers per floors strategically placed at the first story, roof and at intermediate stories without the need to directly measure the ground motion. The specific location of sensors can be determined using optimal sensor placement algorithms that minimize the conditional variance of the response estimate based on acceleration measurements. Validation tests carried out in real instrumented buildings made of steel, reinforced concrete and wood confirm this finding subject to increasing levels of strong shaking. The estimated stresses and strains can be used to rapidly assess the condition of an instrumented building following an earthquake by using stress/strain related metrics, such as demand-to-capacity ratios. These are very familiar to structural engineers and are found in all modern building codes.

b)      The response estimation algorithms developed during this research project, known as “model-based state estimators” show significant robustness against a wide range of modeling errors typically found in structural engineering practice. In addition, and in contrast with other response estimation algorithms, model-based estimators can be implemented directly as a modified finite element model of the structure. This allows for model-data fusion using sophisticated and nonlinear state-of-the-art structural models.

c)      The research from this project resulted in the development of a new framework for structural health monitoring of structures subjected to cumulative damage such as fatigue. The framework relies on an algorithm capable of optimally combining the predictive capabilities of multi-scale finite element models with that of sensor measurements to reconstruct the complete dynamic response of a structure. The reconstructed response allows assessment of the state of cumulative fatigue damage throughout the structure, thus anticipating potential damage before it reaches a critical level. Once the state of damage together with its uncertainty is determined, the condition of the structure is projected into the future in order to perform probabilistic damage prognosis. The framework was verified using computational models, and validated using laboratory experiments and real data from a minimally instrumented operational bridge deck.

This project partially funded the studies of five(5) PhD students and several undergraduate researchers. Funding from this project enabled the principal investigator to communicate research findings in conferences, professional meetings, and engage in outreach activities for K-12 students involving classroom visits, hands-on learning, experiments, as well as public lectures.


Last Modified: 01/07/2022
Modified by: Eric Hernandez
